raw.author: Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite
contexts:
Through Neoplatonism these images entered the Christian tradition via the sixth-century works of Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite.
In his Celestial Hierarchy and Divine Names, he represents God as “light,” “fire,” and a “fountain of light.”

He conceived of the deity as unfathomable and contradictory, describing something that is “not a material body, and therefore does not possess outward shape or intelligible form, or quality, or quantity, or solid weight; nor has It any local existence which can be perceived by sight or touch.… It is not soul, or mind, or endowed with the faculty of imagination, conjecture, reason, or understanding … nor is It number or order, or greatness … nor is It personal essence, or eternity, or time … nor is it darkness, nor is It light, or error, or truth …”
commentaries: The author references Pseudo-Dionysius’s texts as foundational to the medieval Christian conception of divine light, highlighting his symbolic association of God with luminous metaphors.

The author cites Pseudo-Dionysius as the first to articulate the problem of representing the sacred, using his negative theology to illustrate the limits of language and imagery in describing the divine.

raw.author: Saint Bonaventure
contexts:
Yet medieval man was fascinated by monsters.
In the first instance people admitted the principle whereby, although ugly things and beings exist, art has the power to portray them in a beautiful way.
We think this is a modern criterion, but Saint Bonaventure said that “the image of the Devil is beautiful when it portrays the Devil’s turpitude well.”
And, as Saint Bonaventure said, “imago diabolo est pulchra, si bene repraesentat foeditatem diaboli”—the image of the devil is beautiful if it is a good representation of ugliness.

It is not that these men were heretics. Simply, with respect to the theological debates of past centuries, they were interested in other things. Today we would say that they dealt with the workings of the mind. These men were more or less consciously killing their fathers, just as the humanist philosophers would later try to kill them—outdated modernists that they were by then—but all the humanist philosophers succeeded in doing was to sentence them to hibernation in the university lecture halls, where contemporary (by which I mean today’s) universities would eventually rediscover them.
commentaries: The author cites Saint Bonaventure to demonstrate that medieval thought already recognized a form of aesthetic beauty in the truthful depiction of moral ugliness, challenging modern assumptions about the history of aesthetic theory.
The author quotes Saint Bonaventure to illustrate the theological idea that depicting ugliness well can itself be an aesthetic achievement.
The author cites Bonaventure as a canonized scholastic thinker whose work diverged from the emerging logica modernorum, highlighting the tension between theology and logic in medieval thought.

raw.author: Homer
contexts:
James Joyce—who took the Homeric narrative form as his model.
Even the ultramodern Ulysses sailed farther thanks to the shoulders, or in this case the mainmast, of an ancient tradition.

We know perfectly well that in reading a work of fiction we make a tacit pact with the author, who pretends to say something true and we pretend to take him or her seriously.
Yet we do not consider statements in novels as lies, nor do we accuse Homer or Cervantes of having been liars.
Oedipus and Achilles were fluctuating entities like Anna Karenina or Pinocchio...
The belief in the Homeric gods whose conspiracies explain the history of the Trojan War is gone.
commentaries: The author cites Homer’s epic structure as the formal backbone of Joyce’s Ulysses, emphasizing that modernist innovation is built upon and sustained by classical narrative models.
The author cites Homer as an exemplar of ancient fiction-writer whose works are not judged as lies, illustrating the cultural acceptance of fictional truth.
The author cites Achilles as an example of a mythological semiotic object, implicitly referencing Homeric epic tradition as the source of the character's enduring cultural properties.
The author invokes Homer as a symbolic reference point for ancient explanatory frameworks of societal events through divine conspiracy, used to contrast with modern conspiracy theories.

contexts: They were the leading lights—as we were told at school—in a battle against the medieval world... Yet what did Renaissance Platonism do? It set Plato against Aristotle, discovered the Corpus Hermeticum or the Chaldean Oracles, and built a new knowledge upon an ancient wisdom that antedated Jesus Christ.

A holist maintains (rightly) that the notion of space has a different meaning in the Aristotelian and Newtonian systems, thus making them incommensurable...

Achilles will cover his unit of length in his unit of time. There is also talk of topological paradoxes, and some have said that the Möbius strip is paradoxical. I find nothing paradoxical about it. It may seem improbable that a twist suffices to turn a two-sided surface into a single-sided one, but in fact it happens, and we have seen this; all this means is that topology is a little more complex than Euclidean geometry. There are far more serious paradoxes, one of the most famous of which is the barber paradox proposed by Bertrand Russell. It comes in an ingenuous version and a subtler one. The first is: “The village barber shaves all the men who do not shave themselves. Who shaves the village barber?” Obviously, he cannot shave himself because he only shaves those who do not shave themselves, and it is presumed that no others in the village are appointed to shave anyone. I put this paradox to my children when they were young and they suggested three solutions: perhaps the village barber is a woman; or the barber does not shave and has a very thick beard; or the barber does not shave but rather burns off his beard, no doubt leaving his face horribly scarred. Actually, the paradox should be stated like this: “Among the inhabitants of a village there is one and only one barber, a well-shaven man. The sign above his shop says, ‘the barber who shaves all those who do not shave themselves.’ The question at this point is: Who shaves the barber?’ Modern logic and mathematics have proposed many antinomies for the resolution of very subtle problems that I will not deal with here. Rather, I shall limit myself to mentioning some other successful antinomies—for example, this one, cited by Aulus Gellius. The story goes that Protagoras gave legal training to a promising young man, Evatlo, and he required Evatlo to pay only half the fee upfront, saying that the student could pay the rest when he won his first case. Evatlo, however, did not go on to practice law, but went into politics instead, and so he never won his first case because he never actually had one.
commentaries: The author references Aristotle as the medieval orthodoxy that Renaissance humanists sought to displace by returning to earlier, pre-Christian authorities.

contexts: It is not that these men were heretics. Simply, with respect to the theological debates of past centuries, they were interested in other things. Today we would say that they dealt with the workings of the mind. These men were more or less consciously killing their fathers, just as the humanist philosophers would later try to kill them—outdated modernists that they were by then—but all the humanist philosophers succeeded in doing was to sentence them to hibernation in the university lecture halls, where contemporary (by which I mean today’s) universities would eventually rediscover them.

Thomas Aquinas revolutionized Christian philosophy, but he would have promptly replied to anyone who criticized him (and some did) that he was only repeating what St. Augustine had taught eight and a half centuries before him.
I graduated in aesthetics with a thesis on the problem of beauty, albeit only as I could explore it in a few pages of Thomas Aquinas.
On the other hand, when in the thirteenth century Thomas Aquinas spoke of proportion as one of the three criteria of beauty, he was no longer speaking only in terms of mathematical ratios.
Thomas Aquinas teaches that three qualities are required for beauty—first among them wholeness or perfection—so that incomplete things, precisely because they are incomplete, "are ugly."
This is the theory put forward by Thomas Aquinas, for example, but also by Lenin in his Materialism and Empirio-Criticism (1909).

Thomas Aquinas, for example, held that embryos had only a sensitive soul, like the animals, and therefore as they are not yet human beings with a rational soul they will not take part in the resurrection of the flesh.
Thomas Aquinas said that the criteria for beauty are proportio and claritas (and these would seem clear) but also integritas.
Aquinas would not have hesitated to define a glass saw as ugly.
recall that Aquinas said that pulchra dicuntur quae visa placent, we call those things beautiful that have been seen and which please us

The author cites Aquinas again to reinforce the classical criteria for beauty and ugliness, linking incompleteness directly to aesthetic failure.

The author cites Thomas Aquinas as an authority on the theological classification of the embryonic soul, using his view to illustrate how definitions of personhood and soul have historically varied.

The author references Aquinas’s philosophical framework for beauty, specifically his concept of integritas (wholeness), to illustrate medieval standards of perfection and their implications for human physicality.
The author cites Aquinas as a key thinker who linked beauty to functional proportion, using the example of a glass saw to illustrate that beauty requires suitability to purpose.

contexts: Consider the Divine Comedy, which has given rise to many trivia games, or Dante cryptography, where what matters for the faithful is to recall certain memorable lines, without posing themselves the problem of the poem as a whole.

And then there are the visions of light that blaze in Dante’s Paradiso, which, oddly, were rendered in their greatest splendor by a nineteenth-century artist, Gustav Doré.

What we feel in trying to understand them is precisely the sense of powerlessness expressed by Dante in the last canto of the Paradiso (XXXIII, 82–86) where he would like to tell us what he saw when he was able to look upon the divinity, but all he can manage to say is that he cannot put it into words...
